contentrichtext.text: :''For the moon of Saturn named after Fárbauti, see '''[[Farbauti (moon)]]'''.'' In [[Norse mythology]], '''Fárbauti''' ([[Old Norse]]: "cruel striker") is the [[jötunn]] husband of [[Laufey|Laufey or Nál]] and the father of [[Loki]], and possibly also of [[Helblindi]] and [[Byleistr]]. He is attested in the ''[[Prose Edda]]'', written in the 13th century by [[Snorri Sturluson]], and in the poetry of [[Viking Age]] [[skald]]s. Fárbauti's name and character are thought to have been inspired by the observation of the natural phenomena surrounding the appearance of wildfire. In the ''Prose Edda'' book ''[[Gylfaginning]]'', the enthroned figure of [[High, Just-As-High, and Third|High]] says Loki is the son of the jötunn Fárbauti and that "Laufey or Nál is his mother".<ref name=FAULKES26>Faulkes (1995:26).</ref> In ''[[Skáldskaparmál]]'', Fárbauti receives another three mentions. In chapter 16, ''[[kenning|Lokakenningar]]'' or "ways of referring to Loki" are provided, one of which reads "son of Fárbauti and Laufey, or Nál".<ref name=FAULKES76>Faulkes (1995:76).</ref> In chapter 17, a work by the 10th century [[skald]] [[Úlfr Uggason]] is quoted referring to Loki as "Fárbauti's terribly sly son".<ref name=FAULKES77>Faulkes (1995:77).</ref> In chapter 22, Fárbauti is referenced in the ''[[Haustlöng]]'' of 10th century skald [[Þjóðólfr of Hvinir]], where Loki is referred to as "Fárbauti's son".<ref name=FAULKES87>Faulkes (1995:87).</ref> ==Interpretation== If, as according to Axel Kock, ''Fárbauti'' as "dangerous striker" refers to "lightning", the figure would appear to be part of an early nature myth alluding to wildfire (Loki) being produced by lightning (Fárbauti) striking dry tinder such as leaves (Laufey) or pine needles (Nál).<ref>Simek (1995:93); Kock (1899:101-102).</ref> Though not directly attested in any original source, scholars have considered Loki's brothers, [[Helblindi]] and [[Býleistr]], to also be sons of Fárbauti.<ref>Rydberg (2003:24); Sykes (2002:85); Guelpa (2009:123-124).</ref> However, their exact role in the presumably ancient mythic complex surrounding Loki's family remains largely unclear.<ref>Simek (1995:174); Kock (1899:100-102).</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== {{refbegin}} *Faulkes, Anthony (Trans.)
